question: Question_07_(b)
statement:
Let $f(x)$ = \emph{x}\textsuperscript{2} - 6\emph{x} and let
\emph{P} be the point (4, -12).

b) Find the slope of the line between \emph{P} and a point (\emph{a},
\emph{a}\textsuperscript{2} - 6\emph{a}) on the curve \emph{y} =
$f(x)$.
sols:
We have two points:

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
(4, -12) \qquad (a, a^2-6a)\end{align*}

So the slope, \emph{m}, of the line going through these two points is
the ratio of rise (change in the y-coordinates) over run (change in the
x-coordinates):

\begin{align*}m = \frac{(-12) - (a^2-6a)}{4-a} = -\frac{a^2-6a+12}{4-a}\end{align*}
hints: The slope of a line is the ratio of rise over run.
